properties.areaDesc: Pickens, SC; Oconee, SC; Anderson, SC
properties.headline: Flood Advisory issued January 3 at 5:26PM EST until January 3 at 11:45PM EST by NWS Greenville-Spartanburg SC
properties.description:
The National Weather Service in Greenville-Spartanburg has extended
the

* Flood Advisory for...
Northern Anderson County in Upstate South Carolina...
Central Pickens County in Upstate South Carolina...
Southeastern Oconee County in Upstate South Carolina...

* Until 1145 PM EST Friday.

* At 518 PM EST, Doppler radar indicates the earlier heavy rainfall
has ended across Anderson, Oconee, and Pickens counties; however, an
area of 1-3 inches of rainfall occurred between approximately 9:30am
and noon, causing flooding of low-lying areas and roadways. Excessive
runoff from this rainfall is still working through area streams.
While most small streams have crested and receded, larger streams
including Eighteenmile Creek are still out of banks and are just now
cresting.  Therefore, it will take several more hours for larger
streams to crest and fully recede below critical levels.  Therefore,
the Flood Advisory will be extended until these larger streams fall
below Action/Advisory Stage.

* Several reports of flooded roads were received by local media
and law enforcement earlier this afternoon, especially in the urban
centers of Central, Clemson, Easley, and Pendleton.  These roads
included: Grant Street in Easley, Central Road in Pendleton,
Isaqueena Trail and Berkeley Road in Clemson, and Pinedale Road in
Central.  While most floodwaters have receded along smaller streams,
residual flooding of poorly draining areas and areas adjacent to
larger streams may continue for a few more hours. It is important
to continue to heed all barricades and seek an alternative route,
especially at night.

* The following streamgauge exceeded Action/Advisory Stage:
Eighteenmile Creek at SC 28 in Pendleton.

Current Stage: 11.43 feet and cresting.
Forecast: Eighteenmile Creek will fall below Action/Advisory Stage
before midnight tonight.
Action Stage: 10.5 feet.
Minor Flood Stage: 12.0 feet.
Impacts: At 11.0 feet the creek will be flooding low-lying areas
adjacent to SC 28 and flooding of Bishop Branch Rd. and Central Rd.
is likely.

* Some locations that may continue to experience residual flooding
include...Easley, Clemson, Seneca, Powdersville, Piedmont, Central,
Pendleton, Liberty, Norris and Townville.
properties.instruction:
Turn around, don't drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood
deaths occur in vehicles.

Be especially cautious at night when it is harder to recognize the
dangers of flooding.
